title.narrative: SWE-2010-193 Toxic elements exposure and micro-nutritional status of communities near Ethiopian Rift Valley Lakes
SWE-2010-193 Toxic elements exposure and micro-nutritional status of communities near Ethiopian Rift Valley Lakes

description.narrative: This study concerns exposure to toxic metals and essential elements in a population living around the Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes (ERVLs) whose life is directly linked to lake resources for fishing and irrigation. Measurements of toxic and essential elements in hair, blood and urine, and information on the daily intakes of these elements from foods and drinking water will be used to assess health risks and nutritional status. The population eats a variety of fish, vegetables grown and irrigated by water from the lakes, and uses some of these potentially contaminated lakes and hot springs for drinking and other domestic purposes. The hypothesis is that the exposure to toxic metals through dietary sources such as fish and vegetables, and drinking water is high. Yet, nothing is known about the exposure level or health effects caused by toxic metals among the study population.

This study concerns exposure to toxic metals and essential elements in a population living around the Ethiopian Rift Valley lakes (ERVLs) whose life is directly linked to lake resources for fishing and irrigation. Measurements of toxic and essential elements in hair, blood and urine, and information on the daily intakes of these elements from foods and drinking water will be used to assess health risks and nutritional status. The population eats a variety of fish, vegetables grown and irrigated by water from the lakes, and uses some of these potentially contaminated lakes and hot springs for drinking and other domestic purposes. The hypothesis is that the exposure to toxic metals through dietary sources such as fish and vegetables, and drinking water is high. Yet, nothing is known about the exposure level or health effects caused by toxic metals among the study population.
